results.name: Table by antidiagonals of generalized Lucas numbers: T(n,k) = T(n,k-1) + n*T(n,k-2) with T(n,0)=2 and T(n,1)=1.
link: G. C. Greubel, Antidiagonals n = 0..100, flattened
formula: T(n, k) = 2^(1-k)*Sum_{j=0..floor(k/2)} binomial(k, 2*j)*(1+4*n)^j. - _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 27 2020
maple: seq(seq( 2^(1+k-n)*add( binomial(n-k, 2*j)*(1+4*k)^j, j=0..floor((n-k)/2)), k=0..n), n=0..13); # _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 27 2020
program: (MAGMA) [2^(1+k-n)*(&+[Binomial(n-k,2*j)*(1+4*k)^j: j in [0..Floor((n-k)/2)]]): k in [0..n], n in [0..13]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 27 2020
def T(n, k): return 2^(1-k)*sum( binomial(k, 2*j)*(1+4*n)^j for j in (0..floor(k/2)) )
[[T(k,n-k) for k in (0..n)] for n in (0..13)] # _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 27 2020
